reviewText:
Permadeath platformer mmo. Basically the weirdest combinations of 3 words to describe a game. Starbreak is really different from the games you’re used to playing.
-Tight controls, although they take some getting used to at first.
-Great soundtrack.
-Large scale boss battles. Think Terraria large.
-Not pay2win

My thoughts as an ex-player of Realm of the Mad God:
I think this game expands on the fundamental ideals of rotmg very well.
There isn't too much grinding to find equipment, while in realm you need to get lucky to find potions/equipment. In Starbreak, the equivalent of stat potions are dropped frequently.
Because of this, the game rewards skill by progressing you quickly, but an unskilled player will be met with permadeath. This challenges players to master the different zones and learn enemy attack patterns, and it challenges new players to reach a higher mark/defeat a higher zone every life.
High end characters are a lot stronger than new ones, but not as much as they were in realm.

Verdict?
I think this game is great, and it can only get better as more content is added. You should try it, but keep in mind that this type of gameplay isn't for everyone.

This is like a 2d sidescrolling destiny!

I really I would have heard about this game sooner, I really do. They have had a website out for quite some time now! So you can either play it through steam or through there site. Either one works, and there is no difference.

StarBreak is an amazing 2D side scrolling game, filled with action and A LOT of players! It amazed me at how many people were actually with me while doing an area! 30 People at once, fighting a boss is absolute MADNESS and thats what rocks about it!  Fight with friends or with randoms in completing certain areas. Its so difficult its fun. Not only that, but this FREE game is actually FREE. The stuff that you can decide to pay for are all simple cosmetics that no one will really notice anyway, so it doesnt matter if you actually get it or not. This game was meant to be played, and played for free. Nothing in this game is any sort of P2W BS that many other free games have these days. I believe thats why this game will explode on steam. We just need to give a few weeks, and by then this game will be one of the best releases on steam.  I really do enjoy this game, I play it every day.

The games art style and playtype isn't somethign that you see now a days. It is a shooter, but a platform shooter. It is a platform shooter, but you can only shoot in certain directions. There is no free aim mode or anything like that. Sounds pretty lame doesnt it? Thats the difficulty of it! One of the key points in this game though, is that once you die, you lose everything that the character had! All those hours spent on this character? Ha! To bad! He is now dead, and so is your spirit. You may now close the game to rethink your gaming life. You will feel that a few times while playing this game, but I can assure you that is never the end.

With 4 different classes, each one can become unlocked after a few levels. So if you dont like the beginning class, you are forced to grind on it untill you gain enough account levels to use the next character. One you die, you gain experience based on how well you played that character. It is VERY grindy, but in the end it doesnt really matter ;)

So dude, like what will make me want to play this game? For starters, this isnt a starter game. It will take time to get into the feel of the game before you can really get into it. You in the beginning you may pick it up from time to time, but once you really start to enjoy the game? You might just pick it up before playing anything else that day. Thats how it was for me atleast.

The play style and the graphics are very well done for this game type. The animations and such are very well done too, so bravo on that one!

If you enjoyed Realm Of The Mad God, then you will most likely enjoy this, except this doesnt have all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that ROTMD had.

The challenge that this game brings is great. Your not able to just pick it up, you have to learn what the game does, how it acts and you have to remember what monsters do what attacks, and what those attacks do. Theres a lot of multi proccessing that your mind has to do while playing this game, and depending on that along with your reaction time will depend on how well you play the game. WIth time comes skill, and with skill comes grind.

Bro, theres gotta be something that you dont like about this game The cosmetics that you can buy with real money go away once you die. So, you have wasted money based on your skill. Thats pretty annoying, so if cosmetics could become a perma thing after purchase, that would be great.

The amount of things happening on the screen at once can sometimes be very hard to know whats going on and where. It does help that there is a circle around your own character, but when there are 20 people in the same area, its hard to keep track of where you are. Maybe if you put in a color system, where the player is allowed to change the color of the circle to whatever pleases and catches there eyes better.

Not a whole lot that I can think of at the moment. But once I do find some more stuff I will be putting it in as it comes up.

reviewText:
For Metroidvania (fans of Metroid/Castlevania-style games which includes stuff like Strider, Dust an Elysian Tail, Rogue Legacy, etc.), this is a must-try.   It's essentially a Metroidvania game but with MMO systems and permadeath in place, challenging you to build up characters and play smart to see how far you can get.   Death has its rewards though, as you gain experience which can go towards unlocking new classes (called Shells) that offer different playstyles.

While you can just rush along with the other players running to the right towards the next area, I personally find it more fun to take my time and explore each area before moving on, as you get more powerups and most of the places that are off the main pathway lead to enemies that drop chests full of loot.   Loot of course being potential weapon/equipment upgrades and currency used towards buying more upgrades.

The F2P model seems very fair and so far doesn't feel restrictive or pay to win in any regards.   Stash and Shell Storage seem to be the primary things you can buy with cash shop currency, and are largely conveniences that can lessen the impact of death (as you can store more items for your next Shell or keep Shells that you already geared up on standby).   Only other thing I've noticed with a price tag are stat-less cosmetic head items, with likely more cosmetics to come in the future.

Overall this game shows a lot of promise and doesn't have any of the red flags of normal F2P games.   Definitely a must-try for fans of the Metroidvania genre who like a bit of Roguelike thrown in.

Do not look at the permanent death as a hindrance. In most games it's a big bummer and in this one... it's not much different. You lose everything you are carrying with you and all your stats return to base. However this game makes it so you feel compelled to do better next time.

The premise is simple: Improve yourself trial after trial. You do not gain Exp in srtings of data to your character. You gain experience by playing the game and feeling how the environment and the enemies move. (technically there is a level system but to be honest here it doesn't do anything)

In a true 2D platformer, StarBreak manages to give you the feeling of transversing a foreign planet, much like Metroid. You and everybody in the dungeon must go forward, defeat enemies and come out victorious without losing your life. And if you do, well try better next life! There are four classes (shells) to choose from once you unlock them all. Each of them have different playstyles to suit your taste.
As you defeant enemies you will come across boosters to your stats. These are divided by tiers in which you have to do a Tier II dungeon to get boosters after you complete your Tier I. This helps build progression.

The best thing I can think that this game has is giving you a goal to work for. Everytime after you die, you will see a list of different statistics showing how well you did in that class. But you also have your own hich scores to beat!

StarBreak makes it so you can massage your own ego by saying that you can do better everytime you die and not just repeating the same process of wasting lives over and over to get the same result.

reviewText:
StarBreak is a fun and challenging platformer/dungeon crawler that plays like a combination of Realm of the Mad God and Metal Slug. Though I recommend this game, it certainly isn't suited to everybody.

After choosing from one of four classes (unlocked through exp gained from playing) the player then has to explore levels, fight enemies and eventually kill the boss. Enemies drop stat increases that are capped based on the difficulty of the level and equipment that increase stats and alter your abilities. Ricocheting bullets, bullet spread, armour piercing bullets, to name a few upgrades. I'd like to see more variation, but it still keeps things interesting. The hit-boxes feel tight and accurate, there seems to be no server lag, and I've experienced no frame rate issues.

There is perma-death, and yes, you will die. You will lose your character, you will lose all your inventory (except your stashed items) and you may feel as though you wasted your time. Some people find that frustrating, and that's perfectly fine. I enjoy that death has a weight to it, and that I am genuinely afraid of being killed. I'm terrified to go into the next room in case it's a boss; I'm scared to jump down that hole because of what might be waiting for me; I'm anxious about fighting an enemy that I don't yet fully understand.

Levels are procedurally generated, so every time you repeat a dungeon it's a little bit different. I enjoy them, but I think they're a little too long, and I'd rather get to the more interesting boss fights quicker. The few boss fights I have encountered have been an absolute joy, and so far they've been fantastic, a true highlight. Punishing, to be sure, but oh so rewarding to kill. I'm really looking forward to encountering more of them.

My favourite part of this game is the comradery I built with complete strangers. When you enter a level, other players may already be there, or they may follow you in. Let's say we enter the 1st level with 20 people. The first few sections are an absolute cluster of mayhem and destruction, with enemies mowed down left and right. A few people teleport home because they're low; a few more randomly die. It's disappointing, but you move on. At the mid-boss, a couple more die, lose their character and miss out on loot. I feel bad for them. Now we're a 10 man group, and some of us are low on health.

Despite being low on health, the 10 remaining are strong players, and they all make it to the final boss. But this one is far harder than the mid-boss. At first he seems quick and easy, but the lowest HP member who wasn't prepared for a boss fight dies the moment he gets too close. Suddenly, the boss changes into it's 2nd phase; 2 members are caught off guard, panic, and die. As you're all sure the boss is nearly dead, a few members get too cocky and die getting greedy for damage. By the time the boss falls, 4 of the original 20 remain. The loot tastes like victory, but there was a cost getting here. The fact that death is so harshly punished gives me a real sense of empathy for those that die along the way.

Now onto my least favourite part of this game - the monetisation. If you feel like playing a different class, you have 2 options - die, and lose all the progress of your character, or pay real money and store your character. If you want to store more than 6 items, you have to pay. This is possibly my least favourite form of monetisation. The developers have a great game, and have created inconvenience that you can remove with cash. It thoroughly annoys me, because I'd pay for this game to unlock cosmetics, but I don't want to encourage these atrocious monetisation schemes that revolve around annoying the player into paying. That being said, it could be worse. At least they aren't offering extra lives for money. If any dev reads this, I'd heavily encourage you to rethink your current monetisation.

As a side note, the game is nigh unplayable with a keyboard. If you do not have a controller, do not bother playing. Even with a controller, the controls can be a little awkward. For example, diagonally aiming downwards is incredibly difficult with an analog stick. It's certainly playable, but it could definitely be improved upon.

Overall, I've really enjoyed this game. It's difficult, but rewarding, with great boss design and fun gameplay. That being said, this does not appeal to everyone. Give it a go, but if you find yourself constantly frustrated, find another game.

reviewText:
Before I begin: Don't go down-voting this review because you hate seeing your favorite game getting criticism. Instead, actually read through this review, and take into consideration the things I have to say, as much of what is here could be considered a legitimate reason for viewing a game so negatively. Many issues I will be pointing out here have also been pointed out by not just myself, but others on both sides of the 'aisle'. All I ask is that you allow a guy a moment to offer his opinion.


Seeing as I apparently earned the ire of a few people for being 'negative about a perfect game', I'm rewriting this review to give more people insight into why I cannot recommend this game. I even TRIED to enjoy it, TRIED to play it and see the good in it, even after writing this the first time. As you can plainly see: Not much has changed, and I've only come away from it with more to focus on.

First of all: I still stand by the feeling that this has the 'potential' to be a great game with some pretty interesting mechanics. However, the mechanics are also what make this such a difficult game for me (and others) to like and enjoy. The gameplay is fun when you're on a roll, when you're blasting through enemy after enemy, finding really good gear to use, and just nailing those difficult jumps and attacks when it really matters. But the progression and combat mechanics can also make all of that work you've put into leveling damn-near useless, no matter how good you get.

When you die, you lose everything, including gear and stats. When you enter a new shell, you start back at square 1: bare bones stats, the most basic of weapons, no body or mobility gear, and not one thing to show for the amount of work you put into playing, except for a little pocket change and a tiny handful of experience points. Even then, it's not worth the trouble, as money is currently useless, and your level only dictates which shells you can use.

When out on the field, you pick up stat boosts to enhance your shell's abilities, which is all fine and dandy, as a couple extra HP can mean the difference between life and death. As you collect these stats, you will sometimes find that you max out an ability. This means that you've just maxed out one ability needed for the increase of your shell's MK level! Awesome! But, like I said: You die, you lose it all, and you have to do it all again. The only way to keep those stats is to stay alive through the entire dungeon. What doesn't help is that you have to collect MK II upgrades from harder dungeons, which means...You guessed it. You're gonna lose all that work, and lose that shiny MK II rating. It's not fun, it's not an enjoyable feature, and the only players who claim to see this as enjoyable are the 'hardcore' players, or those who believe the risk-reward system is 'perfect'. Not everyone is a masochist.

If you want to save those stats, plus the gear you managed to scrape up off the ground in a dungeon, you have the choice to purchase the game's premium currency, which can then be used to unlock a shell storage container, allowing you to switch out to another shell when you want to. Buying the currency is the only way to get these handy dandy containers, as, even if you were given the option, you'll almost never be likely to have the cash on-hand to pay for it, seeing as dungeons pay you in literal pocket change.

Oh yeah, you can even buy cosmetics with that same premium currency! But, like every other item in the game, it can be rendered useless, not to mention non-existent, the moment you die. In other words, you're wasting your time and money on something that doesn't even help you. People say it only costs you a few cents, but the amount really starts to add up, as you grab those same items and try a dungeon again. And again. And again. And again. It starts to add up very quickly.

You may be wondering, though: 'Just how easy would it be to die in this game? It all looks easy!'

Trust me. You'll die easily. SO easily, in fact, that you can likely attribute your death to either sluggish framerate, poor terrain generation, enemy placement, or a ridiculous combo of any and all of those things. Or you can attribute it to the often-insane number of players on-screen, which makes jumping and fighting nearly impossible in some situations, and it limits the amount of points you get when you die. Of course, you COULD run a dungeon solo. Wait wherever you spawned in at, give everyone a few minutes to die off or move on, and then you have all of those respawned monsters and a few treasures waiting for you. Just don't expect it to amount to much.

Not only will you be fighting a ton of alien creatures looking to strip away all of those shiny boosts and pieces of gear you've picked up, you'll be fighting the controls as well. If you're using a controller, aiming is VERY clunky, not to mention very frustrating, as it's tied directly to your movement stick (left stick by default, or d-pad). You can only fire left or right, and then diagonally in between those directions. That's it. No shooting straight up or down. There's no precision shooting, and there's little garuntee you'll hit that enemy coming at you at an odd angle, as you have to find that sweet spot to make your shell fire in an upward direction. Controller users also have to wrestle with the VERY unusual right-stick special. Flick your right analog stick up, down, left or right, and you fire off a special skill. It's a pain trying to use that in the middle of a boss battle, especially when you try to quickly go back to your default primary and secondary fire buttons (B and X on Xbox controllers), and more so when you're trying to out-manuever both the boss AND it's minions (wo spawn in so frequently that you'll likely die in a pit of the blasted things).

If you enjoy platforming games, or maybe just enjoy being put through hell for a handful of XP and credits that will do you very little, sure, this game is fun. But for others, myself included, this game just isn't fun. Fighting controls, fighting framerate issues, fighting BS terrain generation and enemy spawning, fighting the game's mechanics...None of that is fun, nor is it worth spending time trying to adjust to it.

And there you have it. My reasons for not enjoying this game, and for not recommending it.

The keyboard control handling is not designed well at all.  Mouse input is not enabled so all of the input must be handled via the keyboard if you do not have a controller/gamepad.  The primary reason why keyboard input is designed poorly which significantly affects the gameplay is using the special combo (its called RS in this game).  Using RS is awkward because either you can use a meta key (shift) plus the direction to boost up/down/left/right (with the default shell) or bind your own keyboard shortcut for each RS direction (up/down/left/right).  This boost requires the opposite direction press.  For instance, if you want to boost forward, you need to hit meta + back arrow.  Its not intuitive and makes controlling the default shell unnecessarily difficult.  It would be so much easier if they implemented mouse control where the boost would go in the direction of where the mouse is pointing.

Input handling for the default shell in my opinion is broken or at the very least horribly designed.  The default shell has the artificial limitation of not being able to move and shoot at the same time unless the shell is in the air.  This limitation does not make any sense and I never played a 2d side scroller that had this requirement.  Imagine playing Contra or any 2d side scroller with this limitation.  Its simply not fun.  And anyone saying 'git good' simply hasn't been alive long enough to understand that the mechanics for 2d side scrollers are well established and adding this limitation does not make sense.

I have heard some say that the default shell would be over powered if they allowed running and shooting.  I say, the rest of their game design is broken if they needed to add this limitation in order to balance the shells.  Running and shooting in a 2d side scroller should be a given.  The developer IS NOT doing anything innovative by adding this limitation and I really do not think anyone needs to 'git good' using such an impractical mechanic.

My advice to the developer is to balance their game within the context of a 2d side scroller.  Allow running and shooting.  Since this game is on Steam, the majority of steam users USE keyboard and mouse input.  Implement mouse aim.  If you do these things, I will change my review as I think the game has potential.

As for now, I simply cannot recommend this title due to the input handling as I think its overall a frustrating experience.

StarBreak provides a fun experience for several hours, until you've really boosted a character and then got killed in some cheap way by a fireball and lost all that progress –– forever. It's absurdly hard to progress with the current permadeath system. The only small, glimmering hope you receive from dying is a marginal amount of XP so that you can eventually buy other 'shells' to die with. Ultimately, the fun of platforming with a dozen other people and seeing your screen light up in a cacophony of neon lasers is outweighed by the fact that whatever effort you're putting into it will amount to nothing when your shell is killed.

The visuals are great, but the microtransactions seem pretty meaningless. The items you buy with in-game currency and even microtransaction money are *still* lost when you die, along with all your boosts, stats, and sense of purpose as to why you're playing this game.

Lastly, I didn't enjoy how the grouping of players would be so variable. If you spawned into a dungeon, you'd spawn with a few other people, no matter how far they were through the dungeon. More often than not, I'd somehow find myself alone on the map within a matter of minutes. Being that even the first dungeon's boss is nigh-impossible to kill by yourself as a MKI or MKII, and that the boss's area seems to lock itself when you enter, you pretty much shoot yourself in the foot if you're not with a group of 5-10 people at all times.

For the player looking to try this:
– It's free, so you've got nothing to lose.
– Stay with the group at all times.
– Get a weapon with more range than the starting shotgun.

Ultimately, StarBreak provides several hours of mindless entertainment, but the excitement quickly drops into cataclysmic nothingness. The visuals are fantastic and the game could run with max settings on a broken toaster. I recommend this game solely because it's free, but I would not recommend pouring any real money into the game, because you will lose whatever you buy.

This is essentially a browser game, and I was extremely surprised with how fun this was. This is extremely fun, challenging, rewarding, and punishing. Permadeath adds so much to the game. You gain a sense of accomplishment when you gear up a bit, find some implants, some exotic gear, reach mk ii, mk iii, etc. and then die due to an unfortunate chain of events. The game has a bit of a learning curve. It will take a lot of time and a lot of deaths to get proficient at any of the characters. Anyone looking for a challenge, I highly suggest playing this game and trying out the first 2-3 tiers of dungeons.

With that said, I also want to mention a huge downside to the game, the higher difficulty areas (very high/extreme). When you die, you lose all of your stat boosts and your gear. The game gives you a storage container to store a second/backup set of gear, but your stats reset back to zero. Getting your stats back up can be a time consuming process, and is basically required if you want to go back into the tier 3/4+ dungeons. This is fine for the first 2-3 tiers of dungeons, but later on a single death just sets you back too much (and dying isn't that hard in the game, especially if there are 20-30+ characters on the same screen).

Overally, definitely reccomend trying out the game for those looking for a challenge. Just be prepared to be a bit disappointed with the later portion of the game.

You have to die in order to level-up, or change character class (unless you pay money)
Cosmetics are lost on death (which happens frequently)
The graphics, although very pleasant, and expertly made, do lend to an overal clutter on screen, making doging enemy fire niegh on impossible when working in large groups.
Bosses do not scale dependant on how many people are in the fight (i.e. with 20, it will be a breeze, on your own, you have a shot in dark at best.

UC (the name of the ingame currency), is more like a dev support token than it is a currency to be bought for pleasure.

Art and sound design are fantastic. The music is almost never going to bore you.
The pace of gameplay allows a team to take the missions at either a leisurely pace, or at breakneck speed, depending on your familiarity with the game.

The community, for the most part, is fairly non-toxic
Unlike many f2p games, it is not trying to shake money out of you (though this is to such an extent, it's also a con)

the gameplay is addaptive to whatever style of action-platforming you like. Melee, lasers, blocking shot's for your friends, ect.

StarBreak is a new MMO action platform game released May 10th, 2016 on steam. As of my video and this review, I have about 3 hours put into the game. The main mechanic of this game comes from the fact that there is permadeath for your suit. Once you die, all progress is loss and you will have to start anew.

This game is the starchild between Megaman and Realm of the Mad God. The Megaman aspect comes from the action platforming, how items are obtained, and the boss battles (which are fairly well designed but far more bullet spongy than the trash mobs would make you think). Everything else is influenced from the Realm of the Mad God. Players start in a lobby with everyone else on the server chosen. They have the ability to enter named instances with up to 39 other players. These instances are unique planets or worlds that having varying tiers of difficulties and rewards to match the difficulty of the instances. Loot is personal, so you don't have to worry about the other 39 players stealing your +1 bullet weapon.

The developers, Crunchy Games, included a premium currency, obtained by paying real money. As of this review, you can purchase cosmetic hats, that are lost upon death, or quality of life upgrades that include more storage space.

If you love Realm of the Mad God and miss the days of classic Megaman, this game is for you. In spite of myself owning Overwatch, XCOM, FFXIV, etc... I've continued to find myself drawn back to the game to slaughter my enemies. I fully recommend trying out the game as I enjoyed my time with it.
